document.title: Node degree and degree sequences
document.text: The set of neighbors of a vertex v is the neighborhood of v and is denoted by N_G(v). Technically, this is the open neighborhood of the vertex (the closed neighborhood would also include the vertex v itself).
The degree of a vertex v in a graph G is the number of vertices in G that are adjacent to v, i.e. the size of its neighborhood: deg_G(v) = |N_G(v)|.

Since every edge is counted twice (once for each one of its incident vertices), the sum of all vertex degrees is twice the size of the graph, i.e. \sum deg_G(v) = 2|E(G)| = 2m, a basic result known as the First Theorem of Graph Theory and also referred to as the Handshaking Lemma Chartrand et al. 2011. Since the sum of all vertex degrees is even, the number of vertices of odd degree must also be even. Moreover, the average degree of a graph G of order n and size m can be easily computed, since it is always 2m/n.
The minimum degree among the vertices of G is denoted by \delta(G), while the maximum degree in G is denoted by \Delta(G). Hence, 0 \le \delta(G) \le deg_G(v) \le \Delta(G) \le n-1 for simple graphs.
When the nodes with the largest degrees in a given network are much more connected that other nodes in the network, they are typically called hubs.

document.title: Degree sequences
document.text:
An integer partition p = (p_1, ..., p_n) where p_i is the degree of the ith highest-degree node in the graph.
p is an integer partition of 2m, i.e. sum p_i = 2m, in undirected graphs, since each edge contributes to the degree of two nodes.
Not all integer partitions correspond to actual graphs. Those that do correspond to actual graphs are called graphical.
It should be noted that different graphs can share the same degree sequence. Therefore there is not a one-to-one mapping between graphs and degree sequences. We could view a degree sequence as a rough description of the graph topology.
An algorithm to build a graph given a degree sequence: the highest-degree node is connected to the following node; the degree sequence is updated by decrementing p_1 and p_2 (and reorder the partition), resulting in a smaller partition; the process is repeated until the degree sequence is full of zeroes (or a negative value appears, which means the graph was not realizable).
The algorithm above is deterministic. If we want a random graphs with the given degree sequence, we can generate them by flipping edges: from (x,y) and (w,z) we create (x,w) and (y,z), which yields a different graph with the same degree sequence (albeit it should be noted that the resulting graph is not necessarily connected).

We can compress a degree sequence by obtaining a degree distribution, which is just the histogram of the relative frequencies corresponding to the different node degrees, which vary from 1 to \Delta(G).
As in any probability distribution, the sum of the values in the degree sequence distribution must add up to 1.

Different kinds of networks exhibit different degree sequence distributions: e.g. - A random network has a degree sequence distribution that obeys a binomial distribution, - and a scale-free network’s degree sequence obeys a power law.

We can also employ the degree distribution to measure the randomness in the graph. From Information Theory, we know that entropy communicates the amount of information provided by a message and is measured in bits. We can obtain the entropy of a degree distribution by computing

This entropy measures the randomness in the graph degree distribution, or the diversity in node degrees, which is minimum when all the nodes have the same degree (i.e. for regular graphs). For regular networks, where P(deg_G(v)=r)=1 for a single degree r, we obtain H(G_{regular}) = - 1 \log_2 1 = 0. The more random the graph, the higher the entropy: at one extreme, regular graphs have no entropy; at the other end of the spectrum, random graphs have very little regularity (and high entropy).

document.title: Directed graphs: In-degree and out-degree
document.text:
In a directed graph, links are directed and we distinguish between
- The out-neighborhood N^+(v) of a vertex v (the set of vertices adjacent to v)
- The in-neighborhood N^-(v) of a vertex v (the set of vertices adjacent from v)

The out-degree deg_{out}(v) of a vertex v is the number of edges with tail v, i.e. deg_{out}(v) = | N^+(v) |
The in-degree deg_{in}(v) of a vertex v is the number of edges with head v, i.e. deg_{in}(v) = | N^-(v) |
The full degree of a vertex is defined by deg(v) = deg_{out}(v) + deg_{in}(v)
The First Theorem of Digraph Theory can be stated as
AVERAGE DEGREE Undirected graphs: \langle d \rangle = 2m/n Directed graphs: \langle d_{in} \rangle = \langle d_{out} \rangle = m/n
VARIANCE Note: Even though \langle d_{in} \rangle = \langle d_{out} \rangle = m/n in directed graphs, \sigma_{d_{in}}^2 might differ from \sigma_{d_{out}}^2.

note.text: According to their in- and out-degrees, nodes in a directed graph can be classified as: isolates (d=0), sources or transmitters (din=0), sinks or receivers (dout=0), carriers (din=dout=1), and ordinary nodes.
